title: About
text: Tesfaye (Sebastiano) Salarin is currently a PhD student in Economics and Management at the University of Trento and a Visiting PhD at the Department of Computer Science of the University College of London with the Financial Computing and Analytics research group. He holds an MSc in Finance from Cà Foscari University. His research focuses on Market Microstructure, High-Frequency Trading, Algorithmic Trading, and Computational Finance. Lately, he has been broadening his research interests to Machine Learning applications and Mathematical Finance, with a specific focus on using NLP models for financial market prediction. He is passionate about learning, FinTech, Blockchain Technology, and Cryptocurrencies. He has teaching experience in Computer Programming with RStudio and Microeconomics (double language: English and Italian). He is also interested in the intersection of LLMs and financial markets. Tesfaye is currently open to opportunities in quantitative research beginning after the completion of his PhD.

text: I am actively involved in research at the intersection of finance, technology, and economics. title: Recent works
section: 1. Salarin, T., et al. (2024). Estimating the short-term stock market reaction to non-financial information: An event-study approach on ESG news.
text:
1. Salarin, T., et al. (2024). Estimating the short-term stock market reaction to non-financial information: An event-study approach on ESG news.

Abstract : Using an event-study approach, this study investigates the intraday stock market response to firm-specific Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) news. Leveraging a unique dataset comprising intraday financial data and 1,381 ESG-related news headlines from 30 Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) companies between January and March 2023, we examine the impact of ESG news on trading volumes and stock returns. News is classified by ESG pillar and sentiment using GPT-4, a state of the art of Large Language Models (LLM). Our findings indicate that environmental news leads to short-term positive stock price reactions, although the effect dissipates beyond a 21-minute window. Social news generates inconsistent and minor market responses, while governance news significantly impacts stock returns, with negative governance news having the most pronounced and persistent negative effects. These results provide new insights into the role of ESG news in high-frequency trading environments and suggest that governance issues might be a crucial concern for investors in the short term.

Keywords: ESG news, ESG sentiment, event-study, intraday stock returns, AI, high-frequency trading

Update: Currently under submission to Journal of Banking and Finance, Generative AI in Finance Special Issue GenAI.
